descendants.content:
🧵 Below, a thermal Image of a Street in Pontcanna, an affluent area of #cardiff, that has the maximum Tree Equity score of 100. Unlike the post above, that has a low score of 77 & is more socially deprived, with a far greater ethnic diverse community.

https://uk.treeequityscore.org

The tree lined street shows up to a 20 Degrees C difference meters apart, but you have a far greater continuity of cooling.

The more trees, the less your health will be impacted by extreme heat.

#trees #climatechange #uk

The image is annotated with spot temperatures. The exposed tarmac records 39.3 Degrees C at the highest, and the lowest in the tree shade on the road records 20.7 Degrees C.

card.title: Tree Equity Score UK
card.description: Find your score and help create Tree Equity in cities and towns across the UK.

descendants.content:
🧵 Aneurin Bevan Statue #Cardiff an economic centre.

Where there's trees you will see significant heat reduction, making the area more comfortable, & desirable to use.

Surfaces exposed to direct sun, soak heat up, this increases day & night temperatures, it's called the #UrbanHeatIsland Effect.

They also reduce the costs of air conditioning, especially combined with living walls, and roofs.

https://www.woodlandtrust.org.uk/protecting-trees-and-woods/benefits-of-urban-trees/

#trees #climate #climatechange #climatecrisis #wales #uk

descendants.content:
🧵 Below are the temperatures recorded in the same heat wave, on the same day at #Cardiff Castle.

Again where there's tree shade you'll see a temperature difference of up to 2O degrees!

Trees make tourist hot spots more desirable to use, whilst improving the economics of the venue.

Much like farm livestock, you'll also see many a tourist seeking the cooling shade of trees.

#treeequity #trees #climate #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateaction #tourism #wales #uk

descendants.content:
🧵 finally, Bute Park, Cardiff Central. We symbolically pictured the wooden mole sculpture there!

Great tree cover within our urban parks not only adds to the cooling effect of a city, & enables greater wellbeing, but they also provide shade, shelter & habitat for urban wildlife. We can forget, like us, #nature can really suffer in extreme heat!

#TreeEquity - life deserves equitable access to trees, & the health & wellbeing they provide.

https://www.woodlandtrust.org.uk/protecting-trees-and-woods/benefits-of-urban-trees/tree-equity/

#trees #EU #UK #Wales

🧵END

descendants.content:
@Beedazzled @CoedCadw
Hungry people pick fruit.
We pick our apples, cook and freeze ones we can't eat soon, store some.

Cherries are unlikely to damage a car (and indeed, an apple is not likely to either), and, are we determined to have cars lining every street?
If so they should perhaps be under roofs which are photovoltaic panels.

The mess is, you know, ecology.

If arrangements need making to deal with food produced where people are, then lets make them.

descendants.content:
@CoedCadw That is insane. What is that a 20° Celsius difference?
20 would be a lot in Fahrenheit. Is that a lot in Celsius? I'm just guessing here it's a lot in Celsius.
If this means there's a 20° difference between a spot in a shaded slightly forested area, and a wide open parking lot or something. That is insane.
I'm not going to lie. I had been seeing something like that but I thought I had finally gone insane but I guess that's what's been happening.

fields.value: https://www.instagram.com/coedcadwcymru/

descendants.content:
@CoedCadw

Good example of why standardised measurements are essential for understanding temperature:

• In shade (white slatted wooden box)
• 2m above grass in open area
• >10m from buildings/roads/stone-walls

Mixing these up is misleading e.g. ... if there were 2 people where these photos were taken, with one saying it's ~40°c and the other saying 22.4°c.

It's also important to understand that the sun doesn't heat the air. It heats objects/surfaces, which then heat the air.
